conclusion: Two harmonic transverse waves propagate in opposite directions along the x-axis.
Wave sources located at x = -0.2 m and x = 1.2 m.
Both waves have speed v = 0.4 m/s and amplitude 2 m.
At t = 0, particles P (x = 0.2 m) and Q (x = 0.8 m) just begin to vibrate.
Particle M is at x = 0.5 m.
The left wave (from x = -0.2 m) is traveling in the positive x direction.
The right wave (from x = 1.2 m) is traveling in the negative x direction.
The leftward-traveling wave's front is at x = 0.8 m (position Q) at t = 0.
The rightward-traveling wave's front is at x = 0.2 m (position P) at t = 0.
The left wave moves from position P (x = 0.2 m) rightward at 0.4 m/s.
The right wave moves from position Q (x = 0.8 m) leftward at 0.4 m/s.
Left wave position: x₁(t) = 0.2 m + 0.4 m/s × t.
Right wave position: x₂(t) = 0.8 m - 0.4 m/s × t.
At the meeting point, x₁(tₘ) = x₂(tₘ), so 0.2 m + 0.4 m/s × tₘ = 0.8 m - 0.4 m/s × tₘ.
Solving for tₘ gives tₘ = 0.75 s.
Verification: x₁(0.75 s) = 0.5 m and x₂(0.75 s) = 0.5 m.
Both waves meet at x = 0.5 m, confirming the solution.
The two waves meet at time t = 0.75 s at position x = 0.5 m (where particle M is located).
